This is a new IRM section that provides additional guidance with respect to identity theft for Small Business and Self-Employed (SB/SE) Field Examination and Large Business and International (LB&I)

) Identity theft occurs when someone uses an individual’s personal such as name, social security number (SSN), or other identifying information without permission to commit fraud or other crimes. Taxpayers may notify IRS when they believe they may have experienced an identity theft incident. these instances, taxpayers must provide documentation to establish that are identity theft victims. ) If an identity thief has used a taxpayer’s SSN for filing purposes, tax tration is affected. Identity theft can affect tax administration in two primary ways: (cid:
) Employment or Income Related—This occurs when the identity thief the victim’s SSN to obtain employment, resulting in what may appear as unreported income under the victim’s account. (cid:

) Refund Related—This occurs when the identity thief uses the victim’s to file a false federal income tax return to obtain funds. If the thief files before the victim, the victim may not receive his or her refund within a sonable time frame. See IRM
, Identity Protection Program Servicewide Identity Guidance. (

) When tax administration is affected, the examiner must determine if the tax year(s) impacted have identity theft tracking indicator(s). If tracking already exist on a tax year, do not input the “same” code(s) for the tax year. See IRM
, Identity Theft Tracking Indicators. (
) The taxpayer should provide a Form
, Identity Theft Affidavit, or a report in support of an allegation of identity theft. Form

is used to both tax-related and non-tax related identity theft issues. Reminder: A taxpayer is required to provide substantiation documentation to IRS only once per incident. Any business unit that requires

Section A and Section B, to determine if multiple years were affected by the identity theft. If more than one year is involved and indicators are not on one of the years, follow the in IRM
, Overview—Identity Theft Supporting Documentation, to determine if additional documentation is needed or if the multiple year can be updated based on documentation previously submitted.

) Sometimes tax returns not filed by the true owner of a SSN are selected for audit. Unless a taxpayer’s account reflects that he or she has been subject identity theft or the taxpayer received correspondence regarding the return filed, the taxpayer probably has no knowledge of the return filed by else. You may tell a taxpayer that he or she may be a victim of identity theft, but you may not disclose information that identifies the person who filed the tax return. To authenticate the true taxpayer, see IRM
, Identity Supporting Documentation. (

) Any information relating to the Service’s determination of the victim’s tax liability for the year can be disclosed to the victim as his return information. This would include any information relating to the victim’s original balance or refund that was based on the amounts reported on the fictitious Form U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, or the erroneous Form W-

, Wage and Statement, and the underpayment or overpayment as later adjusted. The cause of the events on the taxpayer’s account—suspected identity theft and use of the SSN on another return—would also be disclosable to the victim the taxpayer’s return information. See IRM
, Identity Theft and Access to Information Returns, for additional guidance. (

) Any other information about the Service’s investigation into the civil or tax liability of the person who misused the SSN should not be disclosed to victim. This includes the fictitious return (e.g., Form
), related reporting documents (e.g., Form W-
or Form
-MISC, Miscellaneous Income,) or the identity and investigation of the perpetrator. See IRM
, Identity Theft and Access to Information Returns.
